lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Democratic debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: U.S. Restricts Sales to ZTE, Saying It Breached Sanctions
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — ZTE is one of China’s few truly international electronics firms. Yet American companies will now need special permission to sell to it.

headline: South China Sea Buildup Brings Beijing Closer to Realizing Control
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the aircraft carrier John C. Stennis and four other American warships sailed into the South China Sea last week for what were described as routine exercises, the message was clear: The United States is the dominant military power in the region and plans to keep it that way.

headline: Trying to Read Donald Trump, in Translation
lead_paragraph: You would think that if the leader of a country friendly to America likened a serious contender for the American presidency to two of the premier villains of the 20th century, it would set off an uproar.

headline: Transcript of the Democratic Presidential Debate in Miami
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Democratic debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Obama Criticizes the ‘Free Riders’ Among America’s Allies
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama believes that Saudi Arabia, one of America’s most important allies in the Middle East, needs to learn how to “share” the region with its archenemy, Iran, and that both countries are guilty of fueling proxy wars in Syria, Iraq and Yemen.

headline: The Neocons vs. Donald Trump
lead_paragraph: THERE they go again. The neocons who led the George W. Bush administration into Iraq are now touting a fresh crusade to save American democracy — and the Republican Party — from an authoritarian foe: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Justin Trudeau’s White House Dinner Has the Air of a Family Reunion
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada mounted the carpeted steps of the White House’s North Portico on Thursday night for one of this city’s most glamorous rituals, a state dinner, he followed in his father’s footsteps — but only so far.

headline: Transcript of the Republican Presidential Debate in Florida
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Trade and Tribulation
lead_paragraph: Why did Bernie Sanders win a narrow victory in Michigan, when polls showed Hillary Clinton with a huge lead? Nobody really knows, but there’s a lot of speculation that Mr. Sanders may have gained traction by hammering on the evils of trade agreements. Meanwhile, Donald Trump, while directing most of his fire against immigrants, has also been bashing the supposedly unfair trading practices of China and other nations.

headline: Fill In the Foreign Policy Blanks
lead_paragraph: The next president will have to set the direction of the fight against terrorism, define America’s role in the Syrian war, which has created a refugee crisis that is destabilizing Europe, and address the tensions between China and its neighbors that could turn into military conflict.

headline: Five Big Questions After a (Shockingly) Civil Debate
lead_paragraph: When and why did an alien gain control of Donald Trump’s body?

headline: Morning Agenda: Start-Up Investors Are Not Waiting for Growth
lead_paragraph: START-UP INVESTORS ARE NOT WAITING FOR GROWTH | Investors may be throwing money at mature start-ups like Uber and Airbnb at soaring valuations, but the venture capitalists who can pick a winner early on are the ones who come out on top,Katie Benner and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times.

headline: Bernie Sanders Rallies in Four States to Spur Voter Turnout
lead_paragraph: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — Bernie Sanders, campaigning at a feverish pace on Monday, made last-minute pitches to supporters on the eve of crucial primaries, holding five rallies in four states as he seized on his anti-trade message to rally people to turn out to vote on Tuesday.

headline: Trump’s Brain and U.S. Foreign Policy
lead_paragraph: For weeks, journalists have been asking Donald Trump, the Republican frontrunner for president, to name his foreign policy brain trust. Okay, it doesn’t have to be a panoply of knowledgeable people; how about even a handful?

headline: What Donald Trump Gets Pretty Much Right, and Completely Wrong, About China
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing Donald Trump seems sure about, it is that the United States is getting a raw deal from China.

headline: Study Finds Public Pension Promises Exceed Ability to Pay
lead_paragraph: When Detroit went bankrupt in 2013, investors were shocked to learn that the city had promised pensions worth billions more than anyone knew — creating a financial pileup that ultimately meant big, unexpected losses for Detroit’s bondholders.

headline: Morning Agenda: TransCanada to Buy Columbia Pipeline Group
lead_paragraph: TRANSCANADA TO BUY COLUMBIA PIPELINE GROUP | TransCanada will buy the Columbia Pipeline Group for $10.2 billion after failing to obtain approval for its Keystone XL oil sands pipeline,Ian Austen reports in DealBook.

headline: Donald Trump’s Rise Reverberates Around the World
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s march toward the Republican presidential nomination has sent shock waves through American politics and, as he continued gobbling up delegates this week, the rest of the world has started quivering, too.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Salah Abdeslam, European Union, Donald Trump
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: U.S. Casts Wary Eye on Australian Port Leased by Chinese
lead_paragraph: DARWIN, Australia — The port in this remote northern Australian outpost is little more than a graying old wharf jutting into crocodile-infested waters. On a recent day, there was stifling heat but not a ship in sight. “Our pissy little port,” as John Robinson, a flamboyant local tycoon, calls it.

headline: As Obama Visits Cuba, China’s News Media Weighs In Warily
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — If President Obama was looking for encouragement after his meeting with President Raúl Castro of Cuba in Havana, the Chinese news media was not the place to find it.

headline: Obama, in Havana Speech, Says Cuba Has Nothing to Fear From U.S.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — President Obama on Tuesday made a full-throated plea for Cuba’s autocratic government to change, calling on President Raúl Castro to loosen his grip on the economy and political expression or risk squandering the fruits of a historic thaw.

headline: The Unsettling Acquisitiveness of Anbang, a Chinese Insurer, in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: A buying spree by a Chinese insurance company that has emerged seemingly overnight is flashing a warning sign.

headline: Dangerous World, Serious Leaders
lead_paragraph: There is starting to be a sad, somber repetitiveness to the horror of terror attacks and the world’s reaction to them.

headline: Abortion Rights Advocates Cry Foul at New Step in Fetal Tissue Inquiry
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A special House committee empaneled to investigate fetal tissue research is preparing to issue 17 subpoenas to medical supply companies and laboratories, seeking the names of researchers, graduate students, laboratory technicians and administrative personnel — and prompting charges of intimidation.

headline: Obama Expresses Regret for U.S. Policies During Argentina’s ‘Dirty War’
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Obama expressed regret on Thursday for the failure of the United States to acknowledge the brutal repression and atrocities that took place during Argentina’s “dirty war” in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: In Donald Trump’s Worldview, America Comes First, and Everybody Else Pays
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential front-runner, said that if elected, he might halt purchases of oil from Saudi Arabia and other Arab allies unless they commit ground troops to the fight against the Islamic State or “substantially reimburse” the United States for combating the militant group, which threatens their stability.

headline: Transcript: Donald Trump Expounds on His Foreign Policy Views
lead_paragraph: Over two telephone conversations on Friday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, discussed his views on foreign policy with Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger of The New York Times. Here is an edited transcript of their interview (or just the highlights).

headline: Highlights From Our Interview With Donald Trump on Foreign Policy
lead_paragraph: Over two telephone conversations on Friday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, discussed his views on foreign policy with Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger of The New York Times. Here are some excerpts we highlighted (and an edited transcript).

headline: Obama’s Last Tango
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — BARACK OBAMA is tangoing into history, and there’s something perfect about that.

headline: The Trade Deficit Isn’t a Scorecard, and Cutting It Won’t Make America Great Again
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump believes that a half-trillion-dollar trade deficit with the rest of the world makes the United States a loser and countries with trade surpluses like China and Mexico winners.

headline: How the G.O.P. Elite Lost Its Voters to Donald Trump
lead_paragraph: The manufacturing executives had gathered in an Atlanta conference room last year to honor their senior United States senator, Johnny Isakson, for his tireless efforts on their behalf in Washington. But as the luncheon wound down, Mr. Isakson found himself facing a man from Coweta County. The man, Burl Finkelstein, said trade policies with Mexico and China were strangling the family-owned kitchen-parts company he helped manage, and imperiling the jobs it provided. Mr. Isakson politely brushed him off, Mr. Finkelstein recalled, as he had many times before.

headline: Trump's New World Disorder
lead_paragraph: Goodbye to all that. Now we know that Donald Trump would rip up the post-1945 world order, trash an “obsolete” NATO, lean toward a Japan with nukes rather than the “one-sided agreement” that leaves the United States responsible for Japanese defense, tell Saudi Arabia that it “wouldn’t be around for very long” without American protection, and generally make clear that “we cannot be the policeman of the world.”

headline: Comments by Donald Trump Draw Fears of an Arms Race in Asia
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Donald J. Trump’s suggestion that Japan and South Korea should take more responsibility for their defense, including possibly developing their own nuclear weapons, has provoked worries in Asia about the potential for a regional arms race.

headline: Obama Faces a Tough Balancing Act Over South China Sea
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When dozens of world leaders gather for a summit meeting in Washington on Thursday, President Obama will meet privately with only one of them: President Xi Jinping of China.

headline: Lew Defends Sanctions, but Cautions on Overuse
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With an eye to President Obama’s legacy and his own, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew on Wednesday will hail the success of economic sanctions against Iran and other global offenders, but warn that their overuse could threaten the primacy of the United States and the dollar in the world economy.

headline: China Air Quality Study Has Good News and Bad News
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — You’re moving to China with your family, and you’re excited but also concerned: What might the country’s notorious smog do to your and your children’s lungs?

headline: Patrolling Disputed Waters, U.S. and China Jockey for Dominance
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHANCELLORSVILLE, in the South China Sea — The Navy cruiser was in disputed waters off the Spratly Islands when the threat warning sounded over the ship’s intercom: “Away the Snoopie team. ... Away the Snoopie team.”

headline: Bernie Sanders, Buoyed by Poll, Sprints Through Wisconsin
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont spent Wednesday crisscrossing Wisconsin, hosting events in three cities and arguing that his stances on trade deals, campaign finance and foreign policy make him a stronger candidate than Hillary Clinton.

headline: Shifting From Wisconsin, Hillary Clinton Tells New Yorkers That She’s One of Them
lead_paragraph: With Bernie Sanders making headway in Wisconsin before next week’s vote there, Hillary Clinton turned her energies on Wednesday to winning a more pivotal contest: the New York primary on April 19, where a Sanders victory would be a humiliating outcome for her.

headline: Campaign Season’s Anti-China Tone Is Likely to Cloud Meeting With Obama
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama refused to bash China when he ran for the White House in 2008, which set him apart from other candidates. None of Mr. Obama’s would-be successors are showing similar restraint. Some, like Donald J. Trump, are bashing Beijing with gleeful abandon.

headline: One Envoy’s Take on China’s Hardball Diplomacy
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese diplomats are known to be tough, but it is rare to hear descriptions of how tough. A senior Singaporean diplomat has pulled back the veil and has talked about China’s efforts to put smaller Asian countries in their place.

headline: Activist Says China Didn’t Allow Her to Receive Award in U.S.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A well-known human rights advocate said on Thursday that the Chinese authorities had forbidden her from traveling to the United States to accept an award from Secretary of State John Kerry honoring her bravery.

headline: As Obama Hosts Nuclear Security Summit, the Focus Is on China
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama gathered more than 50 world leaders here on Thursday to discuss one of his favorite topics: locking down nuclear weapons. But it was Mr. Obama’s meeting with one of the less friendly of those leaders, President Xi Jinping of China, that captured most of the attention.

headline: White House Assails Donald Trump Proposal to Let Asian Allies Get Nuclear Weapons
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House official said on Thursday that it would be “catastrophic” to adopt a proposal by Donald J. Trump, the Republican front-runner, that Japan and South Korea manufacture their own nuclear bombs to deter North Korea.

headline: Obama and President Xi of China Vow to Sign Paris Climate Accord Promptly
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China said Thursday that they would sign the Paris Agreement on climate change on April 22, the first day the United Nations accord will be open for government signatures.

headline: Obama Rebukes Donald Trump’s Comments on Nuclear Weapons
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday questioned Donald J. Trump’s fitness for office after statements from the Republican front-runner that the United States and its allies should move away from decades of constraints on the use of nuclear weapons. “We don’t want somebody in the Oval Office who doesn’t recognize how important that is,” Mr. Obama said.

headline: Global Warming Linked to Public Health Risks, White House Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Global warming could lead to an increase in allergies and asthma, deaths by extreme heat and the proliferation of insect-borne diseases such as the West Nile virus, according to a scientific report released Monday by the White House.

headline: Donald Trump, Despite Bashing Beijing, Is Not Without Fans in China
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Last month, as Donald J. Trump’s lead in the Republican presidential primaries widened and his feud with the party establishment intensified, Ding Qiushi, a chemist in Nanjing and founder of the online “Trump Fan Club,” sang his praises: “A political outsider is taking the country by storm, with unflinching courage.”

headline: The Dark History of Defending the ‘Homeland’
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the screenwriter and producer Alex Gansa finished the script for a political thriller involving a deeply troubled C.I.A. agent and a soldier who had been turned by the Taliban, and began thinking about a title. He recalls that he wanted a word or phrase to conjure an atmosphere of “creepy subversion” — something sinister, xenophobic, un-American. “Shadowland”? No, not quite. “Homeland”? Perfect.

headline: Impossible Missions
lead_paragraph: I just read a book that Barack Obama and Donald Trump would both enjoy.

headline: A Treasury Secretary at the Center of Obama’s Most Pressing Policies
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s second-term Treasury secretary, has kept such a low profile in these relatively placid economic times, compared with his crisis-era predecessor, that it seemed he might end up best known for his pending decision to pick a woman for portraiture on the $10 bill.

headline: Tabloid Editor and Ex-Diplomat Square Off Over China’s Foreign Policy
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An unusual public spat between a Chinese ex-diplomat and the top editor of a well-known tabloid newspaper has set off debate on one of the paper’s favorite subjects: Beijing’s foreign policy.

headline: In Cambodia, the Ghosts Prefer Dollars
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — One recent morning, Suon Sokhum, a colonel in the Cambodian Army, was shopping for gifts for his ancestors.

headline: Donald Trump’s Trial Balloons Are Catching Up With Him
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, Donald J. Trump said he could live with a nuclear-armed Japan and South Korea if it meant they could defend themselves against North Korea without American aid. “I’m not sure that would be a bad thing for us,” he said.

headline: Kerry Visits Hiroshima Memorial and Underlines U.S.-Japan Alliance
lead_paragraph: HIROSHIMA, Japan — Secretary of State John Kerry attended a memorial ceremony in Hiroshima on Monday for victims of the American atomic bombing 71 years ago, becoming the highest-ranking United States administration official to visit the site of one of the most destructive acts of World War II.

headline: Morning Agenda: How Valeant’s Missteps Derailed Female Viagra
lead_paragraph: HOW VALEANT’S MISSTEPS DERAILED FEMALE VIAGRA | In August, Sprout Phamaceuticals was flying high: It had finally received regulatory approval for its drug Addyi to treat low sex drive in women, and a day after the Food and Drug Administration approved the drug, Valeant Pharmaceuticals International bought Sprout for $1 billion, twice its value only two months earlier. But a series of missteps after the deal, combined with problems at Valeant that have depressed its stock by 85 percent, derailed what was once hailed as the “female Viagra,”  Katie Thomas and Gretchen Morgenson write in The New York Times.

headline: Eye on China, U.S. and Philippines Ramp Up Military Alliance
lead_paragraph: MANILA — After a rocky patch of 25 years, the United States and the Philippines will solidify a new, increasingly complex military relationship this week, driven partly by China’s assertive actions in the South China Sea.

headline: Taiwan Denies Role in Spy Case Involving U.S. Navy Officer
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s military denied any involvement on Tuesday in the case of a United States naval officer under investigation on suspicion of providing secret information to Taiwan or China.

headline: U.S. and India Agree to Strengthen Military Ties

headline: Race for Latest Class of Nuclear Arms Threatens to Revive Cold War

headline: How Hillary Clinton Became a Hawk
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton sat in the hideaway study off her ceremonial office in the State Department, sipping tea and taking stock of her first year on the job. The study was more like a den — cozy and wood-paneled, lined with bookshelves that displayed mementos from Clinton’s three decades in the public eye: a statue of her heroine, Eleanor Roosevelt; a baseball signed by the Chicago Cubs star Ernie Banks; a carved wooden figure of a pregnant African woman. The intimate setting lent itself to a less-formal interview than the usual locale, her imposing outer office, with its marble fireplace, heavy drapes, crystal chandelier and ornate wall sconces. On the morning of Feb. 26, 2010, however, Clinton was talking about something more sensitive than mere foreign affairs: her relationship with Barack Obama. To say she chose her words carefully doesn’t do justice to the delicacy of the exercise. She was like a bomb-squad technician, deciding which color wire to snip without blowing up her relationship with the White House.

headline: Morning Agenda: New Limits on Bankers’ Pay
lead_paragraph: NEW LIMITS ON BANKERS’ PAY | It has taken several years, the Dodd-Frank overhaul and bouts of outrage over Wall Street pay, but regulators have released new rules intended to restrict executive pay at big financial institutions,Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook.

headline: Obama Calls Meeting With European Leaders Over Shared Challenges

None of those Harvard bastards!” he bellowed at his chief of staff H. R. Haldeman. Yet when it came time to pick a national security adviser, he chose Henry Kissinger, a Harvard professor who today embodies the East Coast foreign policy establishment.

headline: 1966: Building Bridges to Peace
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara called today [May 18] for steps to ‘‘build bridges’’ toward Communist China as a means of avoiding war. ‘‘We can do so with properly balanced trade relations, diplomatic contacts, and in some cases even by exchanges of military observers,’’ Mr. McNamara said. His statement was the strongest yet in a series of pronunciations by top U.S. officials indicating a change in attitude toward China. Vice-President Hubert Humphrey recently advocated the ‘‘containment without isolation’’ of China. Mr. McNamara said there were practical alternatives to the current U.S. relationships with both China and the Soviet Union. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 19, 1966
