lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China and the United States once acted like opposites when it came to governing the internet.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A visit to Taiwan by an American cabinet secretary. A sale of advanced torpedoes. Talk of starting negotiations over a potential trade agreement.

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The grainy photograph certainly said something about China and the Pacific: It showed the Chinese ambassador, Tang Songgen, walking over the backs of 30 people on a remote island in the nation of Kiribati soon after he had landed on a grassy airstrip.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials have tried taking a political sledgehammer to China over the coronavirus pandemic, asserting that the Chinese Communist Party covered up the initial outbreak and allowed the virus to spread around the globe.

headline: To Deal With China, Trump Should Learn German

It will be a much more aggressive China, a China looking to supplant American technology dominance, smother democracy in Hong Kong and cybersteal your personal data. Pushing back on that China, without blowing up the global trading system, will require reversing one of Donald Trump’s biggest mistakes — his failure to build a partnership with Germany to counter Beijing.

headline: TikTok Deal Is Complicated by New Rules From China Over Tech Exports

Countries like Japan and France pushed companies to shift production from China. The pandemic had crippled China’s factories by the end of January.

headline: TikTok Deal Faces Complications as U.S. and China Ratchet Up Tit-for-Tat
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On most days, companies like ByteDance, Microsoft, Walmart and Oracle are considered kings within their fields. But over the weekend, it became increasingly clear that they can also be something else: a set of pawns.

headline: America, Don’t Try to Out-China China

headline: Forget TikTok. China’s Powerhouse App Is WeChat, and Its Power Is Sweeping.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese government has stopped renewing press credentials for foreign journalists working for American news organizations in China and has implied it will proceed with expulsions if the Trump administration takes further action against Chinese media employees in the United States, according to six journalists and U.S. officials with knowledge of the events and statements on Monday by a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman.

headline: Joe Biden’s China Journey

headline: Your Monday Briefing
lead_paragraph: Nearly 300 people were arrested during protests in Hong Kong on Sunday, the day when a legislative election was initially scheduled to take place. Thousands of police officers in riot gear filled the streets.

headline: Xi’s Post-Virus Economic Strategy for China Looks Inward
lead_paragraph: He inspected fields of corn amid jitters about food supplies. He visited steel works trying to overcome a slump in profits. He toured an innovation center at a time when President Trump has raised barriers against China’s technological takeoff.

headline: Duterte Pardons U.S. Marine Who Killed Transgender Woman
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has pardoned an American Marine convicted of killing a transgender woman, just days after his office blocked a court order to free the service member, the Philippine foreign secretary said on Monday.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is weighing a ban on some or all products made with cotton from the Xinjiang region of China, a move that could come as soon as Tuesday as the United States looks to punish Beijing over alleged human rights violations, three people familiar with the matter said.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Commission on Tuesday named Valdis Dombrovskis, a former Latvian prime minister and senior European Union official, as its new trade chief in a reshuffle following the resignation of the Irish commissioner Phil Hogan last month.

headline: From Asia to Africa, China Promotes Its Vaccines to Win Friends
lead_paragraph: The Philippines will have quick access to a Chinese coronavirus vaccine. Latin American and Caribbean nations will receive $1 billion in loans to buy the medicine. Bangladesh will get over 100,000 free doses from a Chinese company.

headline: Europe Feels Squeeze as Tech Competition Heats Up Between U.S. and China
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Lacking a powerful technology sector of its own, the European Union has instead tried to carve out a space in the digital economy as the world’s regulatory superpower, leading the charge on privacy rights and data protection by leveraging its enormous single market against Goliaths like Google and Facebook.

headline: A Violinist Lost His Seat and His Job. He Blames China.

headline: Oracle Chosen as TikTok’s Tech Partner, as Microsoft’s Bid Is Rejected

headline: Trump Is Wrong About TikTok. China’s Plans Are Much More Sinister.

headline: U.S. Official Visits Taiwan, and China Warns of Consequences

headline: China Sends Warning to Taiwan and U.S. With Big Show of Air Power

headline: Trying to Hammer Iran With U.N. Sanctions, U.S. Issues More of Its Own

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing

They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases have meandered through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.

headline: China’s Combative Nationalists See a World Turning Their Way

Americans have embraced communism and Manhattan, draped with the hammer-and-sickle flags of the “People’s Union of America,” has become a quaint tourist precinct.

headline: China Brings Moon Rocks to Earth, and a New Era of Competition to Space

This time, it will be a competition over resources on the moon that could propel deeper space exploration.

headline: Takashi Oka, Journalist Who Interpreted Japan for U.S., Dies at 96

headline: With Hacking, the United States Needs to Stop Playing the Victim

Politicians of both parties have called it a virtual act of war. “America must retaliate, and not just with sanctions,” Senator Marco Rubio said.

headline: Biden Is Expected to Expand U.S.-India Relations While Stressing Human Rights

headline: Pompeo Weighs Plan to Place Cuba on U.S. Terrorism Sponsor List

headline: China Has All It Needs to Vaccinate Millions, Except Any Approved Vaccines

headline: Trump Was Briefed on Uncorroborated Intelligence About Chinese Bounties

headline: U.S. Companies Face China Tariffs as Exclusions Expire

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union embarked on a trade deal with China believing that engagement with Beijing was the best way to alter its behavior and make it a committed stakeholder in the international system. But that was seven years ago.

headline: State Dept. Moves to Ease Restrictions on Meeting With Taiwan Officials

headline: Protesters Who Fled Hong Kong Arrive in U.S., Seeking Asylum
lead_paragraph: Last July, five young men boarded a recreational boat in a remote harbor in Hong Kong. They passed through waters patrolled by the Chinese authorities and headed east, across the South China Sea.

headline: U.S. Says China’s Repression of Uighurs Is ‘Genocide’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department declared on Tuesday that the Chinese government is committing genocide and crimes against humanity through its wide-scale repression of Uighurs and other predominantly Muslim ethnic minorities in its northwestern region of Xinjiang, including in its use of internment camps and forced sterilization.

headline: The U.S. calls China’s repression of the Uighurs ‘genocide,’ echoing Biden’s earlier comments.
lead_paragraph: The State Department declared on Tuesday that the Chinese government is committing genocide and crimes against humanity through its wide-scale repression of Uighurs and other mostly Muslim ethnic minorities in its northwestern region of Xinjiang, including in its use of internment camps and forced sterilization.

headline: Trump Bequeaths Biden an Upended World

headline: In Confirmation Hearings, Biden Aides Indicate Tough Approach on China
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s top intelligence, foreign policy and military advisers sought to draw distinctions with the departing Trump administration and lawmakers looked for hints about the new approach, as the Senate opened confirmation hearings for three nominees on Tuesday.

headline: Trump’s Last-Minute Moves Against China Complicate Biden’s Agenda
